title: Tarragon Toxicity? | NutritionFacts.org
author: Michael Greger M D FACLM
description: Decades ago, concern was raised about some of the components of the herb tarragon. The European Union's Health & Consumer Protection Scientific
cleaned_text: components of the herb tarragon. The European Union's Health & Consumer Protection Scientific Committee on Food concluded that one of the constituents may act as a carcinogen and damage DNA, and so recommended its use be restricted. But they were talking about an isolated chemical from tarragon being used as a flavoring agent in items like beverages, canned fish, oils. As concluded that consumption of the tarragon leaves themselves should present little or no risk, but that was based on studies done on rats. A 2012 [study](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23010670) made me feel better, suggesting that while the isolated tarragon chemical was toxic to human liver cells, full extracts of the leaves were not, so the whole food may contain compounds that counteract the toxic effects. I was going to leave it at that and not even do a video about it, but a 2013 [study](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23010670) on human white blood cells reopened the question, finding that whole leaf tarragon extracts may have DNA damaging properties after all. I show the results of the comet test in my 3-min video [The Safety of Tarragon](https://nutritionfacts.org/es/video/the-safety-of-tarragon/). For those scratching their heads over the significance of that red smudge, see my explanation of the comet tail mutagenic, however the current data is "not comprehensive enough to draw definitive conclusions regarding its potential risk to human health an of the... potential toxicity." So what have I taken away from all my family eats tarragon so rarely that it's probably not going to change our intake you're dash of fennel or anise seed, or chervil, all of which have a similar licorice-like tarragon taste. The only caveat I is that you probably shouldn't pick it wild, as it bears a resemblance to an herb known all too well to Socrates (poison hemlock). For those that missed my last two videos on the safety of common spices, see [Update on Cinnamon for Blood Sugar Control](https://nutritionfacts.org/es/video/update-on-cinnamon-for-blood-sugar-control/) and Eat Too Much Nutmeg](https://nutritionfacts.org/es/video/dont-eat-too-much-nutmeg/). This new tarragon finding reminds me a bit about the in vitro data raising questions about the safety of in a population [study](https://nutritionfacts.org/es/questions/actualizacion-sobre-los-datos-de-los-aguacates-in-vitro/). I'll keep an eye out for new data and post to the NutritionFacts.org [Facebook page](https://www.facebook.com/NutritionFacts.org) if I find anything.
